docs.lead_paragraph: Following is the roll-call vote of 346 to 85 by which the House today approved a bill aimed at balancing the budget by 2002, culling savings from Medicare and creating a new children's health-care program. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting yes were 193 Republicans and 153 Democrats. Voting no were 32 Republicans, 52 Democrats and 1 independent. X denotes those not voting. There are no vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Republicans -- Aderholt, Y; Bachus, Y; Callahan, Y; Everett, Y; Riley, Y. Democrats -- Cramer, Y; Hilliard, N. ALASKA Republican -- Young, X.
docs.abstract: Tally of votes in House on bill aimed at balancing budget by 2002, culling savings from Medicare and creating new children's health-care program, approved 346-85
docs.snippet: Following is the roll-call vote of 346 to 85 by which the House today approved a bill aimed at balancing the budget by 2002, culling savings from Medicare and creating a new children's health-care program. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the...

docs.lead_paragraph: With both Republicans and Democrats claiming victory and credit, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to approve landmark legislation to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Across the Capitol, debate began this afternoon on the same bill in the Senate, where the legislation enjoys even greater support.

headline.main: Budget Bill Clears House as Senate Takes Up Its Debate

docs.abstract: House votes, 346-85, to approve landmark bill to balance Federal budget by 2002; both Republicans and Democrats claim victory and credit; most of opposition comes from far ends of political spectrum of both parties; bill calls for cutting Medicare spending by $115 billion over five years and cutting Medicaid spending in period by $13.6 billion, provides $3 billion in block grants to states for welfare-to-work programs and $24 billion in health care coverage for uninsured children; is seen key achievement for Pres Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich and Sen Trent Lott (M)
docs.snippet: With both Republicans and Democrats claiming victory and credit, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to approve landmark legislation to balance the Federal budget by 2002.    Across the Capitol, debate began this afternoon on the...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street's chief fear has been that wage increases will exceed inflation, depressing corporate profits and igniting an inflationary wage-price spiral. Main Street's chief fear has usually been the opposite: that wage increases will fail to keep pace with inflation, lowering real living standards and forcing more family members into work. Six years of economic recovery have generated 13 million net new jobs and the lowest unemployment rate in 24 years. Market analysts and the Federal Reserve have carefully watched for signs that the tightest job market in memory might fuel inflation. The slight increase in employment costs that the Labor Department reported Tuesday was scrutinized for its effect on inflation. Sensing little inflationary pressure, the market hit a new high.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Alan B Krueger of Princeton University says US economic policy must address slow growth of wages and fringe benefits among vast majority of America's workers; says there is room for wage growth to accelerate without igniting inflation'; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget bill sailing through Congress this week would significantly broaden restrictions on the use of Federal money for abortions. It would write such restrictions into permanent law, as part of a new program that provides $24 billion for health care of uninsured children and teen-agers in the next five years.

headline.main: Provision on Youth Health Insurance Would Sharply Limit Access to Abortion

docs.abstract: Budget bill passed by House would significantly broaden curbs on use of Federal money for abortions, writing curbs into permanent law as part of new $24 billion program to provide health care for uninsured children; Pres Clinton, who backs budget bill, strong opposes new curbs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Blue Shield of California, seeking to add about 200,000 members to its managed-care plans, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Care America Health Plans and the CareAmerica Life Insurance Company for $175 million. The CareAmerica companies, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., are for-profit units of Unihealth, a not-for-profit holding company. With the added members, Blue Shield of California, a not-for-profit insurer based in San Francisco, will have a total of about 1.8 million in its plans and about $2 billion in revenue.

headline.main: BLUE SHIELD OF CALIFORNIA TO BUY TWO COMPANIES

docs.abstract: Blue Shield of California, which seeks to add about 200,000 to its managed-care plans, agrees to buy Care-America Health Plans and Care-America Life Insurance Co for $175 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Set Records, With the Dow Up 53 Stocks reached new highs, buoyed by economic reports that pointed toward low inflation and moderate growth. The Dow industrials surged 53.42 points, to 8,174.53. Financial companies, American Express in particular, and companies that tend to prosper when the economy is doing well, like Caterpillar, were the catalysts. $(Page D8.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME adolescents may be adding three shots of the hepatitis B vaccine to their list of back-to-school necessities this fall. In the last two years, about two-thirds of state health departments have taken steps to require hepatitis B vaccinations for all adolescents. Hepatitis B is a viral liver disease that is a leading cause of liver transplants.
docs.abstract: Many states are undertaking campaigns to vaccinate pre-adolescents and adolescents against hepatitis B, chronic disease that is one hundred times as contagious as HIV, and can be transmitted through sexual contact, ear piercing, tattoos or other means; school innoculation programs noted (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget agreement would set aside $24 billion in the next five years for a new program to finance medical care for children without health insurance. The details of this program were among the last items approved by Congressional Republicans and White House officials on Monday night.

headline.main: $24 Billion Would Be Set Aside For Medical Care for Children
headline.kicker: THE BUDGET DEAL: Details of Some Provisions Covering Children, Health, and Welfare -- HEALTH

docs.abstract: Federal budget accord calls for setting aside $24 billion for states to provide medical care for uninsured children; would give states range of options in deciding what benefits to offer; table (M)
docs.snippet: The budget agreement would set aside $24 billion in the next five years for a new program to finance medical care for children without health insurance.    The details of this program were among the last items approved by Congressional Republicans...

docs.lead_paragraph: Today's budgetary bonhomie went beyond tributes to the virtues of bipartisanship, though there was plenty of that from politicians who had been sniping at each other only the day before. This moment of good feelings meant that both parties were cheerfully taking credit for each other's ideas. There was President Clinton on the South Lawn of the White House, adopting the $500-a-child tax credit, the crown jewel of the Republicans' 1994 Contract With America, as his own way to help ''a wide range of middle-class parents, all those who are working hard to raise their children, pay their taxes and be good citizens.''
docs.abstract: Analysis of Pres Clinton's accord with Republican Congressional leaders on plan to balance budget and cut taxes as bipartisan effort; both Democrats and Republicans are cheerfully taking credit for each other's ideas; main thrust of plan reflects Republican thinking and many of specifics are of Republican origin, but each party agreed to proposals that the other party deemed essential (M)
